River levels are rising at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this evening, 04/11/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels remain high on the upper river Ouse due to heavy rain associated with storms Babet and Ciaran. Flooding remains possible in this area. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property, and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Sunday, 05/11/2023.

The unsettled weather which brought strong winds and elevated tide levels along the south coast has now cleared the area. Wind, wave and tide levels are now reducing. Over the next week, tide levels are forecast to be significantly lower than today (04/11/2023) and we are not expecting further flood impacts as a result. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely throughout the afternoon on 04/11/2023 between 02:00 PM and 07:00 PM.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
High water at 04:15 PM will remain high for several hours after high water.
A combination of tide locking and high fluvial flows will result in high water levels.
We are closing locks and flood gates in the area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated  as the situation changes.

items.message: Flooding is possible throughout the daytime of Saturday 4th November and into Sunday morning. Heavy rainfall in the early hours of Saturday morning has caused river levels to rise. Further heavy showers are forecast throughout the day on Saturday. Catchments are saturated, so river levels will remain high and could respond to further rainfall. Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the Tamar River is possible. The main areas of concern are around Tamarstone Bridge and Crowford Bridge. Monitor your local weather conditions and avoid using low lying footpaths or entering areas prone to flooding. Do not walk or drive through flood water. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by midday on Sunday or earlier if the situation changes.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.53m and rising slightly.
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 6.45 m and is rising by less than 10 mm per hour.
There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.
Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible this weekend. 
We are unable to pump at Currymoor due to high river levels. However, we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to try to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. And pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. We will pump at Currymoor when river levels allow.
Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 05/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today Saturday 4 November 2023. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh. The forecast is for showers to get more scattered and less intense as we move into more settled weather. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Sunday 5 November 2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Saturday 4 November, and into next week. High water levels may last for a few days. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads during the current neap tides and high surge levels. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. It is likely we may need to issue more warning messages for a wider area, over the next few days. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes.

items.message: Over the last few days we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Witham area. This means that the River Witham remains high, and we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online if the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from now until tomorrow morning, Sunday 5 November. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Sunday 5 November.

Over the last few days we have seen heavy rainfall in the Barlings Eau and Duckpool catchwater area. This means that water levels remain high and we will continue to see flooding of low-lying land and roads close to watercourses. We expect the rivers to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties is likely and therefore the Lower Barlings and Short Ferry area warning remains in place. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. items.message:
River levels have peaked although they remain above Flood Alert threshold at Weston Bampfylde and Sherborne Lake gauges. 
Areas most at risk include the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.
Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible this weekend. We have checked weed screens in the area. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely.
Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated (or removed) by 05:00 PM on 05/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Following heavy rainfall in the Low Barlings and Short Ferry catchment, water levels in the Barlings Eau remain high. Low lying areas near to watercourses are flooded and we expect properties to be affected. We urge residents in Short Ferry Caravan Park to remain vigilant and stay up to date with the latest advice. Further rainfall is forecast for Saturday 4th November and therefore river levels will remain high. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings. Please avoid contact with flood water. Our staff are out in the area to check the flood defences, clear blockages, and assist the emergency services and council. We will be closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated online and on FloodLine as the situation changes.

items.message: Following Storm Babet and subsequent heavy rainfall, water levels in the Witham Catchment remain high. We are actively monitoring the bank of the river near Fiskerton village, and have installed cameras to monitor the location continuously. We have agreed an action plan with the Local Resilience Forum should circumstances change. We urge residents in Fiskerton village, Short Ferry Caravan Park and properties along Ferry Road area to remain vigilant, and stay up to date with the latest advice. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is likely from now until tomorrow morning, Sunday 5 November. items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse in York due to rainfall associated with Storms Babet and Ciaran. Levels have now peaked and are slowly dropping throughout the night. However, flooding still remains possible. Areas most at risk include riverside properties through central York. Flood gates are closed throughout the city. Our incident room is open and we are carrying out operational activities, including operating the Foss Barrier. Flood gates near the river remain closed. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 06:00 on Sunday, 05/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to recent rainfall.  Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days.   This information is correct as of 13:30 on 4/11/23. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 23 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 1 centimetre of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency is liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close Welney causeway. Today’s rainfall will keep river levels high, while floodwater is also travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes. Avoid driving through flood water. We are monitoring the situation, we will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 5/11/23.

items.message:
Catchments are saturated and further rainfall over the past 24 hours have meant river levels remain high.  Further showers are expected.  Flooding remains possible to low lying areas although no further flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

River levels have peaked although they remain above Flood Alert threshold at the Ashford Mill gauge. 
Areas most at risk include roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. 
Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible this weekend. We have checked weed screens in the area. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely.
Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated (or removed) by 05:00 PM on 05/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station (HEPS) is 8.88 m and is steady.
The drain level at HEPS is 7.94 m and is rising marginally. 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible this weekend. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels closely. We are unable to pump at Huish Episcopi and other pumping stations near Langport due to high river levels. However we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to try to evacuate the water (as downstream tidal levels allow).
Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 05/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Rivers Tillingham and Brede remains in force following a day of heavy rainfall on Saturday 4 November.  Water levels in both rivers are exceeding that observed last Thursday and Friday.  An escalation to Flood Warning conditions is not expected, however we are aware of what appears to be surface water flooding on the Tilling Green estate in Rye. As of Saturday evening, the Tillingham had peaked at Hundredhouse Bridge and was draining through Tillingham Sluice in Rye. The Brede will peak at Brede Bridge around 9pm Saturday evening and at Winchelsea and Rye around 04:30 Sunday morning. Any showers on Saturday evening should die out by midnight. Drier weather is expected on Sunday and Monday.

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall today. The river level on the River Mole has now peaked, however, flooding of roads and low lying land along the River Mole particularly around Horley will continue until tomorrow morning, 05/11/23. No Flood Warnings are currently in force on the River Mole, though we are prepared to issue Flood Warnings if necessary.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours until 1am on Sunday 05/11/23.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/11/23.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen again as a result of the rainfall today.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 7pm today and lunchtime on Monday 06/11/23. We expect flooding to affect areas between Kinnersley Manor and Cobham. River levels are expected to peak between tomorrow morning and evening 05/11/23.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 8 hours until 11pm today.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond when required.  

Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. 

This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 05/11/23, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to continue this evening, Saturday 4th November 2023. River levels are now level and are expected to drop overnight into Sunday the 5th November . Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College.  The forecast is for largely dry conditions with occasional showers through Sunday into Monday.  Avoid walking or driving through flood water - just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message on Sunday 5th November 2023

Levels remain high on the river Derwent at Buttercrambe due to heavy rain associated with storms Babet and Ciaran. Levels are expected to rise a little further and remain high throughout the weekend. Flooding is expected in this area. Our incident room is open and we are closely monitoring the situation. Please take action to protect yourself and your property, and monitor local weather and river conditions. Avoid contact with, walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 23:30 on Saturday, 04/11/2023.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue throughout today, Saturday 4 November and into next week. High water levels may last for a few days. This is due to a natural tide locking effect of the Broads river system and recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are Ridlington, Briggate, Honing, East Rushton, Dilham, Sutton, Catfield Common, Hickling, Potter Heigham, Ludham, Bastwick, Martham, Damgate and Billockby, and the A149 and A1062 roads. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 5 November.

items.description: The Rivers Pant, Blackwater and Brain
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from now until tomorrow morning, Sunday 5 November. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas on the Blackwater from Radwinter to Langford, including Great Sampford, Bridge End, Finchingfield, Bocking, Bradwell, Coggeshall and Kelvedon. And Braintree, Black Notley, White Notley and Witham on the Brain. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Sunday 5 November.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The Flood Alert for the River Medway between Leigh and Yalding remains in force following a day of heavy rainfall on Saturday 4 November.  Water levels are generally not expected to exceed that observed last Thursday and Friday in most locations, however there is a chance the overall water level in Yalding may be slightly higher. Flood Warning conditions are not expected for the Little Venice site. The Ensfield Road near Leigh will remain closed overnight. The Medway will peak through Tonbridge in the early hours of Sunday morning, through East Peckham on Sunday morning and in Yalding early on Sunday afternoon. Any showers on Saturday evening should die out by midnight. Drier weather is expected on Sunday and Monday.

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: Over the last few days we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Nene area. This means that the River levels have risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on Floodline as the situation changes.

Environment Agency Flood Warning Officers set the river or tidal levels that have triggered this message. During industrial action this message has been automatically issued based on rising river or tidal levels.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.53m and rising slightly.
Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m.
The drain level at Currymoor is 6.45 m and is rising by less than 10 mm per hour.
There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.
Further showers are forecast, therefore flooding remains possible this weekend. 
We are unable to pump at Currymoor due to high river levels. However, we are utilising the Parrett Relief Channel to try to evacuate the water away from the Parrett-Tone confluence. And pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. We will pump at Currymoor when river levels allow.
Please consider local water levels, weather conditions and your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low lying footpaths, roads and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 05/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the intense rainfall over the last few weeks. The more westerly communities on the Chalk in Dorset, including those along the South Winterbourne Valley will start to experience issues with septic tanks and roads may become flooded. Levels are expected to continue rising until at least the end of next week. You can monitor groundwater levels at the Kingston Russell borehole on the Check-for-Flooding.gov.uk website.
Further heavy rainfall is expected tomorrow, Saturday with a further band arriving in the middle of next week.
Please avoid driving through flood water as the bow wave can flood nearby properties and can seriously damage your engine. If there is no alternative please drive very slowly to minimise damage. 
If you have property flood resilience measures such as pumps, air brick covers or flood barriers, you should consider putting them in place now. 
This message will be updated on Saturday.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: The Flood Warning for the New Romney Sewage Arm remains in force due to high water levels in the local drainage system following a week of high rainfall accumulations. The Environment Agency are in the process of supplying additional pumping capacity at Greatstone Pumping Station to help draw the water level down. We continue to monitor the level and attend the site on a regular basis.  Any showers on Saturday evening should die out by midnight.  Drier weather is expected on Sunday and Monday.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The River Stour has risen as a result of heavy rainfall on Saturday 04/11/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the River Great Stour, particularly in Wye, Chartham, Canterbury and Fordwich.   
We expect river levels to begin rising at 16:00 on 04/11/23 until 15:00 on 05/11/23. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.  The internal flooding of property is not expected.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses between Wye and Fordwich including Canterbury.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on Sunday 05/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
The River Beult has risen as a result of heavy rainfall on Saturday 04/11/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads close to the river, particularly around Bethersden, Smarden, Headcorn and near Staplehurst.   
We expect river levels to begin rising at 16:00 on Saturday 04/11/23 until a peak around 09:00 on Sunday 05/11/23. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers.  The internal flooding of property is not expected.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses around Bethersden, Smarden, Headcorn and Staplehurst.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on Sunday 05/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole at Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley. Groundwater levels are high and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.

We expect levels to stabilise over the next few days. Low-lying land and roads will therefore also continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message as the situation changes.
